symptoms.name: Fever of unknown origin (FUO)
symptoms.pattern: Insidious onset, high-grade in some cases

symptoms.name: Hypersplenism
symptoms.pattern: Present in some cases, with bleeding manifestations (melaena, hematemesis)

symptoms.name: Abdominal pain
symptoms.pattern: Dull aching pain in left hypochondrium, dragging in nature, non-radiating, gradually progressive

symptoms.name: Frequent bowel movements
symptoms.pattern: Watery stools, not associated with blood or mucus

vital_signs.temperature: Elevated (100.4°F or higher in some cases)

lab_values.ESR: Elevated (64 mm in the first hour in some cases)
lab_values.Acid-fast bacilli (AFB): Positive in sputum in some cases, negative in splenic aspirate in some cases

risk_factors: HIV infection (although cases in immunocompetent individuals are reported)

imaging_findings.Ultrasound: Splenomegaly, multiple small hypoechoic lesions, multiple abscesses (in some cases)
imaging_findings.CT scan: Splenomegaly, multiple hypodense lesions, splenic abscesses (in some cases), large circular lesion of mixed density (in some cases), small patches of low-density liquefaction necrosis (in some cases)
imaging_findings.MRI: Large lesion with high T2 signal, equal or slightly high heterogeneous T1-weighted signal, and visibly high diffusion-weighted signal (in some cases)

required: Histopathological examination of splenectomy specimen showing epithelioid granulomas with caseous necrosis
supportive: Clinical presentation with FUO and splenomegaly
Positive AFB stain or culture (although often negative)
Imaging findings suggestive of splenic lesions
